  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath8 be an arbitrary field and @xmath9 an @xmath10 matrix with non negative integer entries @xmath11 and with non - zero columns .",
    "let @xmath12 $ ] and @xmath13 $ ] be two polynomial rings over @xmath8 .",
    "denote by @xmath14 the monomial @xmath15 , where @xmath16 .",
    "a _ binomial _ @xmath17 in @xmath12 $ ] is a difference of two monomials , i.e. , @xmath18 for some @xmath19 .",
    "an ideal generated by binomials is called a _",
    "binomial ideal_. consider @xmath20 the graded homomorphism of @xmath8-algebras @xmath21 \\rightarrow k[t_1,\\ldots , t_m ] \\ , \\mbox { induced by } \\ , \\varphi(x_i)=t^{a_i},\\ ] ] where @xmath22 is the @xmath23_-th _ column of @xmath24 .",
    "the polynomial rings are graded by assigning @xmath25 and @xmath26 for every @xmath27 .",
    "the kernel of @xmath20 , denoted by @xmath28 , is called the _ toric ideal _ associated to @xmath24 .",
    "it is well - known that @xmath28 is a prime graded binomial ideal with @xmath29 ( see for example @xcite ) .",
    "@xmath28 is a _ complete intersection _ if @xmath30 , where @xmath31 denotes the minimal number of generators of @xmath28 .",
    "equivalently , @xmath28 is a complete intersection if and only if there exists a set of homogeneous binomials @xmath32 $ ] such that @xmath33 and @xmath34 .",
    "complete intersection toric ideals were first studied by herzog in @xcite .",
    "after that , they have been extensively studied by several authors ; see for example @xcite and the references there .",
    "it is well known , see e.g. @xcite or @xcite , that the problem of deciding whether a toric ideal is a complete intersection belongs to the complexity class @xmath35 .",
    "let @xmath0 be a simple undirected graph , i.e. , an undirected graph without multiple edges or loops .",
    "set @xmath36 its vertex set , @xmath37 its edge set , and @xmath38 its incidence matrix .",
    "the toric ideal associated to @xmath38 is denoted by @xmath1 .",
    "it is a prime homogeneous binomial ideal called the _",
    "toric ideal of @xmath0_. the image of @xmath20 is denoted by @xmath39 $ ] and called the _ edge algebra of @xmath0_. if we denote by @xmath40 the number of connected components of @xmath0 which are bipartite , then @xmath41 ( see @xcite ) which implies that @xmath42 .",
    "we say that @xmath0 is a _ complete intersection _ if the corresponding toric ideal @xmath1 is a complete intersection .    in this work we study the complete intersection property of graphs from both an algorithmic and a combinatorial point of view .",
    "the complete intersection property for bipartite graphs has been extensively studied ; see for example @xcite .",
    "it is worth mentioning that gitler , reyes and villarreal proved in @xcite that a bipartite graph is a complete intersection if and only if it is a ring graph . since ring graphs are obviously planar , they could derive that every complete intersection bipartite graph is planar , which was previously proved by katzman @xcite without using the notion of ring graph .",
    "when graphs are not necessarily bipartite there is some recent work by tatakis and thoma @xcite , in the last section we make use of some of their technical results . for directed graphs ,",
    "the complete intersection property has also been widely studied , see for example @xcite .    in this work ,",
    "our graphs are undirected and not necessarily bipartite . in this general",
    "setting , the problem requires a different approach .",
    "indeed , figure [ fig1 ] shows an example of a ring graph whose toric ideal is not a complete intersection .",
    "moreover , there exist complete intersection graphs which are not ring graphs ; figure [ fig2 ] shows a complete intersection graph which is not even planar .",
    "-.2 cm    ( 0,45)(0,45 )    ( 10,70)(140,40)[t ]    ( 60,60)(40,60)[r ]    ( 15,30)(150,40)[lb ]    ( 60,40)(60,60)[r ]    ( -60,70)(0,-1)40    ( -60,70)(0,-1)40    ( 20,70)(0,-1)40    ( -20,70)(0,-1)40    ( -60,70)(1,0)80    ( -60,70 )    ( -20,70 )    ( 20,70 )    ( -60,30)(1,0)80    ( -60,30 )    ( -20,30 )    ( 20,30 )    ( 20,30)(1,0)40    ( 20,70)(1,0)40    ( 60,30 )    ( 60,70 )    ( 60,30)(0,1)40    ( 15,10)(1,0)50    the main results of this work are theorem [ principal ] , theorem [ teoremaestructura ] and theorem [ ultimo ] .",
    "the first one yields a polynomial time algorithm which receives as input a simple undirected graph @xmath0 and returns true if @xmath0 is a complete intersection or false otherwise .",
    "moreover , whenever @xmath0 is a complete intersection , the algorithm provides without any extra effort a minimal set of generators of @xmath1 . as a consequence of this algorithm",
    "we obtain that the problem of determining whether a graph @xmath0 is a complete intersection belongs to the complexity class @xmath43 .",
    "given a connected graph @xmath0 , we get a partition of @xmath0 into two disjoint induced subgraphs @xmath3 and @xmath2 such that @xmath44 where @xmath45 are odd primitive cycles , and @xmath2 is bipartite . in this context ,",
    "theorem [ teoremaestructura ] gives necessary conditions for a graph to be a complete intersection by characterizing when @xmath3 is a complete intersection . using this result ,",
    "when @xmath3 is connected and @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected , theorem [ ultimo ] characterizes the complete intersection property on @xmath0 by determining all possible edges connecting @xmath3 and @xmath2 .    in section [ sec2 ]",
    ", we collect some results concerning general toric ideals that will be useful in the sequel .",
    "the main result in this section is proposition [ subconj2 ] , which deals with the problem of when the complete intersection property is preserved by elimination of variables . for toric ideals associated to graphs ,",
    "proposition [ subconj2 ] states that any induced subgraph of a complete intersection graph also has this property .",
    "this is theorem [ induce - ci ] in section [ sec3 ] , which allows us to obtain in theorem [ 2cases ] an upper bound for the number of edges of a complete intersection graph in terms of the number of vertices , improving all previously known bounds ( see corollary [ cotasuperior ] ) .",
    "an immediate consequence of theorem [ 2cases ] is that a complete intersection graph either has a vertex of degree @xmath46 , or is @xmath47-regular ( see corollary [ 2situaciones ] ) .",
    "section [ sec4 ] is devoted to designing algorithm ci - graph , a polynomial time algorithm for checking whether a graph is a complete intersection .",
    "this algorithm is a direct consequence of theorem [ principal ] and works as follows : vertices of degree @xmath48 are removed , also vertices of degree @xmath7 are removed after checking certain conditions ; if these conditions are not satisfied , the algorithm returns false ; otherwise , we iterate this process until we get either a trivial graph or a graph in which every vertex has degree @xmath49 .",
    "if there is a vertex of degree @xmath50 , the algorithm returns false .",
    "otherwise we use the characterization of complete intersection @xmath47-regular graphs given in theorem [ todosgradomayor2 ] .",
    "finally , we use theorem [ fs ] to check if @xmath0 is a complete intersection .",
    "section [ sec5 ] deals with the problem of finding forbidden subgraphs in a complete intersection graph .",
    "the main result is theorem [ notheta ] , where we prove that odd theta graphs whose base vertices are not adjacent , and also even theta graphs , are forbidden subgraphs of a complete intersection graph ( see definition [ thetadefinition ] for a definition of even and odd theta graphs ) .",
    "to prove this , we use lemma [ 2subgrafos ] and proposition [ contraccion ] , two technical results concerning the vertices of degree @xmath7 in a complete intersection graph . in section [ sec7 ]",
    "we apply the previous results in order to obtain the above mentioned theorem [ teoremaestructura ] and theorem [ ultimo ] together with their normal versions ; corollary [ teoremaestructuranormal ] and corollary [ ultimonormal ] .",

    "now we aim to prove that the complete intersection is hereditary , i.e. , if a graph is a complete intersection then every induced subgraph also is .",

    "an almost immediate consequence of theorem [ induce - ci ] is that a graph is a complete intersection if and only if all its connected components are complete intersections .",
    "this allows us to reduce our study to connected graphs .",
    "[ conexo]let @xmath0 be a graph with connected components @xmath162 .",
    "then , @xmath0 is a complete intersection if and only if so are @xmath162",

    "the cardinality of this set is called the _ degree of _ @xmath172 and is denoted by @xmath174 , or @xmath175 when @xmath0 is understood .",
    "@xmath0 is @xmath8-regular if every vertex of @xmath0 has degree @xmath8 .",
    "the following result provides an upper bound for the number of edges of complete intersection graphs .",
    "this gives the taste that they can not be very dense .",

    "the aim of this section is to provide algorithm ci - graph , an algorithm for checking whether a graph is a complete intersection .",
    "this algorithm follows as a consequence of theorem [ principal ] , which is the main result of this section .    by corollary [ 2situaciones ]",
    "we have that a complete intersection graph either has a vertex of degree @xmath46 or is @xmath47-regular .",
    "this section begins with a thorough study of @xmath47-regular complete intersection graphs .",
    "it will turn out in theorem [ todosgradomayor2 ] that a @xmath47-regular graph is a complete intersection if and only if it is an odd band or an even mbius band . to prove this we need some definitions and a technical lemma .",
    "theorem [ todosgradomayor2 ] will be essential for proving theorem [ principal ] .",
    "a _ chain _ is a graph @xmath0 with @xmath220 and edges @xmath221,@xmath222 and @xmath223 for @xmath224 .",

even mbius band except @xmath254 is not planar , theorem [ todosgradomayor2 ] provides an infinite family of non planar complete intersection graphs . both katzman @xcite and gitler , reyes and villarreal @xcite proved that whenever @xmath0 is a bipartite complete intersection then it is planar .",
    "as one can see this result is no longer true if we drop the assumption that @xmath0 is bipartite .",
    "this was first realized by katzman ( * ? ? ?",
    "* remark 3.9 ) , who provided a mbius band with @xmath317 vertices as an example of a complete intersection non planar graph .",
    "later tatakis and thoma @xcite provided another example which is not a mbius band .",
    "we are thus led to the main result of this section .",
    "[ principal]let @xmath0 be a graph without isolated vertices . then",
    ", @xmath0 is a complete intersection if and only if one of the following holds    1 .",
    "@xmath318 of degree @xmath48 and @xmath319 is a complete intersection .",
    "2 .   @xmath318 of degree @xmath7 such that @xmath320 and @xmath321 is a complete intersection .",

    "the connected components of @xmath0 are odd bands or even mbius bands .",

    "suppose that @xmath0 is a complete intersection and let @xmath119 be even closed walks in @xmath0 such that @xmath312 with @xmath343 . by proposition [ generadoresinducido ] and theorem [ induce - ci ]",

    ". since @xmath354 , this is equivalent to @xmath355 .",

    "this theorem yields algorithm ci - graph , see figure [ algoritmo ] , an algorithm to determine if a graph is a complete intersection .",
    "this method begins by removing all the vertices of degree @xmath48 and @xmath7 iteratively .",
    "whenever we remove a vertex @xmath172 of degree @xmath7 , we check whether @xmath356 . in the positive case ,",
    "we construct a set @xmath357 and look for an even closed walk @xmath102 such that @xmath358 .",
    "if such a walk does not exist , then @xmath0 is not a complete intersection , otherwise we take @xmath102 a shortest even walk such that @xmath358 and define the binomial @xmath130 ; one can obtain such an even walk in polynomial time by means of the algorithm proposed in @xcite .",
    "once we have removed every vertex of degree @xmath46 , either we get a trivial graph or we reach a graph @xmath146 where every vertex has degree @xmath359 .",
    "if there exists a connected component of @xmath146 which is neither an odd band nor an even mbius band , then @xmath0 is not a complete intersection .",
    "otherwise we can construct a set of @xmath360 binomials @xmath361 , and @xmath0 is a complete intersection if and only if @xmath312 . for checking this equality",
    "we use theorem [ fs ] .",
    "it is worth pointing out that in @xcite the authors give a polynomial algorithm to decide if a matrix is dominating ; thus one can check if the equality @xmath312 holds in polynomial time .    as a direct consequence of this algorithm we have the following result .    the problem of determining whether a graph is a complete intersection is in the complexity class @xmath43 .",
    "counting the number of connected components of a graph and deciding whether a graph is bipartite , and thus computing @xmath362 , can be done in polynomial time for every graph @xmath210 . to prove the result it only remains to prove that , given a connected graph @xmath210 , one can decide if @xmath210 is either an odd band or an even mbius band in polynomial time . for this purpose",
    "we propose a polynomial time algorithm that returns true if @xmath210 is an odd band or an even mbius band , or false otherwise .",
    "if @xmath210 has @xmath183 vertices then we return true if and only if @xmath363 .",
    "if @xmath210 has more than @xmath183 vertices , the algorithm lies on the fact if @xmath210 is an odd band or an even mbius band with @xmath364 and edges @xmath365 for all @xmath366 , @xmath367 for all @xmath346 ; then @xmath368 for all @xmath122 , @xmath369 for every @xmath370 ; moreover @xmath371 if @xmath210 is an odd band , and @xmath372 if @xmath210 is an even mbius band .",

    "we compute @xmath375 for all @xmath376 and assume that @xmath377 .",

    "this section is devoted to prove that if @xmath0 is a complete intersection and there are three paths @xmath438 and @xmath439 of the same parity connecting @xmath440 that only meet at their ends , i.e. , @xmath441 for @xmath243 , then @xmath438 and @xmath439 are all odd paths and @xmath442",
    ". we will prove this result in theorem [ notheta ] . to prove this",
    "we will first introduce two results concerning the vertices of degree @xmath7 in a complete intersection graph , namely lemma [ 2subgrafos ] and proposition [ contraccion ] .",
    "the first one is a technical lemma which will very useful in the sequel .",
    "the second one describes an operation in @xmath0 that leads to another graph @xmath146 with less vertices and edges than @xmath0 and @xmath146 is a complete intersection whenever @xmath0 is .",

    "the second result concerns an operation in a graph , which is called the contraction of a graph in a vertex of degree @xmath7 .",
    "we will prove that if @xmath0 is a complete intersection , the contraction of @xmath0 in a vertex of degree @xmath7 preserves the property of being a complete intersection .",

    "the converse of proposition [ contraccion ] is not true in general , as one can see in figure [ fig4 ]    ( 150,65)(20,10 )    ( 50,65)@xmath0    ( 12,65)@xmath172    ( 12,5)@xmath535    ( 20,70 )    ( 20,70)(0,-1)60    ( 20,70)(2,-1)40    ( 20,10 )    ( 20,10)(2,1)40    ( 40,50 )    ( 60,53)@xmath536    ( 40,50)(1,0)40    ( 60,50 )    ( 80,50 )    ( 40,30 )    ( 40,30)(1,0)40    ( 40,30)(0,1)20    ( 80,30)(0,1)20    ( 60,30 )    ( 80,30 )    ( 150,65)@xmath466    ( 160,53)@xmath537    ( 140,50 )    ( 140,50)(1,0)40    ( 160,50 )    ( 160,50)(0,-1)20    ( 180,50 )    ( 140,30 )    ( 140,30)(1,0)40    ( 140,30)(0,1)20    ( 180,30)(0,1)20    ( 160,30 )    ( 180,30 )    now we introduce the concept of theta graph and use the previous results to prove theorem [ notheta ] , which asserts that odd theta graph whose base vertices are not adjacent , and also even theta graphs , are forbidden subgraphs in a complete intersection graph .",
    "this is the main result of this section .",
    "[ thetadefinition]a _ theta graph _",
    "@xmath55 with _ base vertices _",
    "@xmath538 is a graph with @xmath539 , where @xmath540 and @xmath439 are three paths of length @xmath541 connecting @xmath542 and @xmath543 such that @xmath544 for @xmath243 .",
    "if @xmath540 and @xmath439 are all even @xmath228respect .",
    "odd@xmath229 paths , then @xmath55 is called an _ even _ @xmath228respect . _",
    "odd_@xmath229 _ theta graph_.    theta graphs are sometimes defined in the literature to have @xmath545 however , from our definition we have @xmath546 ; this is , it might have edges connecting a vertex in @xmath547 and a vertex in @xmath548 with @xmath243 or even connecting two vertices @xmath549 of @xmath550 with @xmath551 and @xmath552 .    to prove theorem [ notheta ] we need a lemma , whose proof is almost immediate .",
    "[ verticeciclopar]let @xmath172 be a vertex of degree @xmath7 and @xmath3 an even cycle such that @xmath553 .",
    "then , @xmath0 is bipartite @xmath554 is bipartite .",
    "let @xmath481 be the neighbors of @xmath172 , then @xmath555 .",
    "hence , if @xmath484 is a bipartition for @xmath186 and @xmath485 , then necessarily @xmath556 , so @xmath557 is a bipartition for @xmath0 .",
    "the other implication is obvious .",
    "[ notheta]neither odd theta graphs whose base vertices are not adjacent nor even theta graphs are complete intersections .",
    "suppose that there exists an even theta graph or an odd theta graph whose base vertices are not adjacent which is a complete intersection .",
    "let @xmath0 be the smallest graph with respect to @xmath558 with this property , we denote by @xmath559 the base vertices of @xmath0 and @xmath560 the three even or odd paths connecting @xmath542 and @xmath543 such that @xmath441 for @xmath561 .",

    "we separate three cases :    * if @xmath614 , then @xmath615 . * if @xmath616 , then @xmath617 * @xmath618 , then @xmath619 .",

    "@xmath623 is an walk of the same parity of @xmath439 connecting @xmath542 and @xmath543 with @xmath624 , but this contradicts again the minimality of @xmath0 .",
    "the goal of this section is to prove two structure theorems for complete intersection connected graphs ; namely theorem [ teoremaestructura ] and theorem [ ultimo ] . given a graph , it can be partitioned into two induced subgraphs @xmath3 and @xmath2 , such that @xmath625 where @xmath45 are odd primitive cycles and @xmath2 is a bipartite graph . note that this partition might not be unique and when @xmath0 is bipartite , one has that @xmath3 is the empty graph .",
    "whenever we have a partition with these properties we write @xmath626 $ ] . in order to characterize the complete intersection property on @xmath0 , we propose to characterize when @xmath3 and @xmath2 are complete intersections , and then determine the admissible edges connecting @xmath3 and @xmath2 . since @xmath2 is a bipartite graph it turns out that it is a complete intersection if and only if it is a ring graph ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary 3.3 ) ) .",
    "theorem [ teoremaestructura ] will give necessary conditions for a connected graph to be a complete intersection by determining when @xmath3 is a complete intersection .",
    "finally , if @xmath3 is connected and @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected , theorem [ ultimo ] characterizes the complete intersection property by obtaining all possible edges connecting @xmath3 and @xmath2 .",
    "we need the following technical result which is included in the proof of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 5.3 ) . recall that a _ block _ is a maximal connected subgraph @xmath84 of @xmath0 such that if one removes any of its vertices it is still connected .",
    "a graph is _",
    "@xmath7-connected _ if it only has one block and more than @xmath7 vertices .",
    "* if @xmath627 , then there exists an @xmath628 such that @xmath629 and @xmath630 for @xmath631 . *",
    "if @xmath139 and @xmath140 are vertex disjoint , then there exist @xmath632 such that @xmath633 and @xmath634 for @xmath635 .",
    "assume that @xmath0 is a complete intersection with three vertex disjoint odd cycles and let @xmath146 be the smallest connected induced subgraph with this property .",
    "we denote by @xmath636 , @xmath637 and @xmath638 three vertex disjoint odd primitive cycles of @xmath146 . by (",
    "* ? ? ? * theorem 4.2 ) , @xmath146 has either one or two non bipartite blocks and the proof falls naturally in two cases .",

    "following theorem [ fs ] we can conclude that @xmath1 is a complete intersection minimally generated by @xmath832 .",
    "this result is a consequence of the fact that the complete intersection property is hereditary ( theorem [ induce - ci ] ) , which allows us to claim that if @xmath833 $ ] is a complete intersection graph , then both @xmath2 and @xmath3 are complete intersection graphs .",
    "thus , by corollary 3.3 in @xcite it follows that @xmath2 is a ring graph and by proposition [ 3impares ] and proposition [ oddpartilband ] it follows that @xmath3 is either the empty graph , an odd primitive cycle , an odd partial band or @xmath3 has two connected components which are odd primitive cycles .      [ contraej ] let @xmath833 $ ] be the graph in figure [ figcontraej ] , where @xmath834 $ ] is an odd primitive cycle and @xmath835 $ ] is a bipartite ring graph .",
    "@xmath2 is a ring graph and @xmath3 is a complete intersection , nevertheless @xmath0 is not a complete intersection because it contains @xmath836 $ ] , which is @xmath209 , as a subgraph ; see corollary [ subgraphk23 ] .    under the hypotheses that @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected and @xmath3 is connected , one has the characterization given in proposition [ propestructura ] . in particular",
    ", this proposition states that there are either @xmath48 or @xmath7 vertices in @xmath2 such that every edge connecting @xmath2 and @xmath3 is incident to one of these vertices . to state proposition [ propestructura ] we need a definition .",
    "@xmath0 is a _",
    "@xmath48-clique - sum _ of two graphs @xmath654 and @xmath837 if it is obtained by identifying a vertex @xmath398 of @xmath654 and a vertex @xmath397 of @xmath837 .",
    "analogously , a _",
    "@xmath7-clique - sum _ of @xmath654 and @xmath837 is obtained by identifying an edge @xmath404 of @xmath654 and an edge @xmath405 of @xmath837 .",
    "[ propestructura]let @xmath833 $ ] be a connected graph such that @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected and @xmath3 is connected . then",
    ", @xmath0 is a complete intersection if and only if @xmath2 is a ring graph and either there exists @xmath838 such that @xmath0 is a @xmath48-clique - sum of @xmath2 and @xmath839 $ ] , with @xmath839 $ ] a complete intersection , or there exist two adjacent vertices @xmath840 such that @xmath0 is a @xmath7-clique - sum of @xmath2 and @xmath841 $ ] , with @xmath842 $ ] a complete intersection .",
    "[ 2verticesvecinos]let @xmath626 $ ] connected graph such that @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected and @xmath3 is connected . if @xmath0 is a complete intersection , then either there exists a vertex @xmath838 such that @xmath0 is a @xmath48-clique - sum of @xmath2 and @xmath843 $ ] , or there exist two adjacent vertices @xmath844 such that @xmath0 is a @xmath7-clique - sum of @xmath2 and @xmath841 $ ] .",
    "assume that @xmath833 $ ] is a complete intersection where @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected and @xmath3 is connected . by theorem [ teoremaestructura ] ,",

    "now we can state and prove the following characterization theorem , which allows us to list all families of complete intersection graphs @xmath833 $ ] such that @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected and @xmath3 is connected .      * a bipartite ring graph , * a @xmath48-clique - sum of a bipartite ring graph and either * * a ci - odd - partial - wheel , * * a @xmath48-clique - sum of an odd partial band and an edge , or * * a ci - vertex - band , * a @xmath7-clique - sum of a bipartite ring graph and either * * a ci - double - wheel , or * * an odd partial band .",
    "@xmath253 since @xmath0 is connected , by theorem [ teoremaestructura ] we have that @xmath2 is a bipartite ring graph and @xmath3 is either the empty graph , an odd primitive cycle or an odd partial band . if @xmath3 is the empty graph , then @xmath1317 is a bipartite ring graph .",
    "otherwise , by proposition [ propestructura ] , either      assume ( 1 ) holds , if @xmath3 is an odd primitive cycle , by lemma [ partialwheel ] we obtain ( b.1 ) , and if @xmath3 is an odd partial band , by lemma [ civertexband ] we obtain ( b.2 ) or ( b.3 ) .",
    "assume now that ( 2 ) holds , if @xmath3 is an odd primitive cycle , by lemma [ doublewheel ] we have ( c.1 ) , and if @xmath3 is an odd partial band , by lemma [ 2oddring ] we have ( c.2 ) .",
    "[ ultimonormal]let @xmath626 $ ] be a connected graph such that @xmath39 $ ] normal .",
    "if @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected , then @xmath0 is a complete intersection if and only if @xmath0 is one of the following graphs :    1 .   a bipartite ring graph , 2 .   a @xmath48-clique - sum of a bipartite ring graph and either * a ci - odd - partial - wheel , or * a @xmath48-clique - sum of an odd partial band and an edge , 3 .   a @xmath7-clique - sum of a bipartite ring graph and either * a ci - double - wheel , or * an odd partial band"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> our purpose is to study the family of simple undirected graphs whose toric ideal is a complete intersection from both an algorithmic and a combinatorial point of view . </S>",
    "<S> we obtain a polynomial time algorithm that , given a graph @xmath0 , checks whether its toric ideal @xmath1 is a complete intersection or not . </S>",
    "<S> whenever @xmath1 is a complete intersection , the algorithm also returns a minimal set of generators of @xmath1 . </S>",
    "<S> moreover , we prove that if @xmath0 is a connected graph and @xmath1 is a complete intersection , then there exist two induced subgraphs @xmath2 and @xmath3 of @xmath0 such that the vertex set @xmath4 of @xmath0 is the disjoint union of @xmath5 and @xmath6 , where @xmath2 is a bipartite ring graph and @xmath3 is either the empty graph , an odd primitive cycle , or consists of two odd primitive cycles properly connected . </S>",
    "<S> finally , if @xmath2 is @xmath7-connected and @xmath3 is connected , we list the families of graphs whose toric ideals are complete intersection .    homogeneous toric ideal , graph , complete intersection    14m25 , 05c25 , 05e40 </S>"
  ]
}
